div.p: Studies 7 and 8 demonstrated increases in NSIB and NSSB using within-group similarities / dissimilarities manipulations. In Study 9 a different manipulation, the homogeneity/heterogeneity manipulation previously used in Study 2 was applied.

Could this manipulation, which is also intended to shift judgmental focus from the internal, within group differences (DIFF L ) to the external differences (DIFF G ), produce the same line of results?
3.7.1 Method.

div.head: Participants.
div.p: There were 337 participants (185 women, M age = 24.67, SD= 4.07) who were asked to participate while they were studying in the libraries at TAU campus.
Participants were offered entry in a raffle for five prizes of 50 NIS (~ $12) in exchange for their participation.

div.head: Measures and procedure.
div.p: Similar to Study 2, participants were asked to compile a group of four movies/musical pieces they liked, either from different genres (heterogeneity

div.head: Sample differences.
div.p: Both the music (N= 171) and movies sample (N=166) were similar on their average bias size (F< 1). A two way ANOVA with questionnaire type (music/movies) and manipulation kind (homogeneity / heterogeneity) on bias size been showed a nonsignificant interaction (F< 1). Therefore, the samples were combined. There was no general order effect (F(3, 1005)= 1.66, p= .17).

div.head: Order effect as a function of the manipulation.
div.p: A separate examination of the effects of the homogeneity and heterogeneity manipulations showed that non-selective superiority biases increased linearly as a function of order only in the similarity-focus condition (F(1, 165)= 5.65, p< .05), but not in the differences-focus condition (F< 1). Two way repeated measures ANOVA with order (first, second, third, fourth) and manipulation (similarity, differences) as independent variables and bias size as dependent, did not find interaction between order and manipulation (F(3, 1005)= 1.01, p= .39) Figure 3 depicts these trends.

div.head: Discussion: Sequential NSSB effects
div.p: This chapter examined the magnitude of bias size when judging all group members one by one against the group's average. Its first section demonstrated that the bias persists when all group membered are sequentially judged; when two rounds of judgments are carried out (with the option to provide new unbiased judgments; and when second round of judgments, involving a new group, is conducted following the first rounds. None of stringent "awareness raising" manipulations made the bias to disappear or even diminish. Studies 4, 5 and 6 examined this issue and provided evidence suggesting that it is hard to eliminate the order effect: in all these three studies, bias size did not diminish across all questions. This was the case when participants had the opportunity to correct the bias in a second round of comparative judgments of the same group (in Study 5) and even of a new group (in Study 6).

These consistent results support the argument that the bias is not easily eliminated. This effect is illogical: Evidently, a situation in which each group member, one-by-one, is perceived as better than their group, is an explicit violation of the basic principle of transitivity (von Neumann & Morgenstern, 1947). However, W-LOGE interpretation of this results suggests that the principle of transitivity is not necessarily broken if the actual comparison is against an external reference, compared to which all group members can be perceived as being superior to others.

It could be claimed that the results of Studies 4-6 demonstrate "no change" effects, and therefore null effects (e.g., Cook & Campbell, 1979;Frick, 1995;Greenwald, 1975), This interpretation is questionable in the current case (see also Cashen & Geiger, 2004;Cortina & Folger, 1998): the persistence of the non-selective superiority bias, despite the augmented familiarity with every additional comparative judgment which provided the judges with active and powerful evidence that the others in the group were also better than "the others in the group" can be viewed as counter-intuitive and even striking. They show that a strong violation of transitivity and in fact of rationality is resistant to correction.

However, even if one adopts the conservative view that the persistence of NSSB along all successive judgments is a null effect, W-LOGE makes even a bolder prediction; namely that the comparative biases, NSSB (and NSIB) can even increase with successive judgments when greater weight is given to the DIFF G during a comparison process. Studies 7, 8 and 9 used within-group similarities manipulations to affect the salience of the difference between the judged local group member (and the others in the group) and the general standard (i.e., the DIFF G ). The results supported the W-LOGE prediction: in the similarities, but not in the dissimilarities condition, the non-selective biases increased with successive judgments. These are the conditions in which judgmental weight is supposed to shift from the internal to the external differences, as demonstrated in the previous chapter.

The persistence of the comparative biases has practical as well as theoretical implications. It has clear effects on the ability to choose from groups or from choice sets. A choice is a process of preferring something over something else (Samuelson, 1953), and thus forming preferences might be difficult or biased when all group members are judged as better compared to all the other group members. Further investigations are needed to explore the influence of sequentially comparing all group members from the same group to all other members in actual choices. For instance, if Anna needs to choose only one musical piece to play at her party, how can she truly choose if there are four highly liked pieces to choose from, and each time she asks herself if this particular piece is better than the others her answer is positive?

Another line of research might inquire under what conditions the bias is reduced over successive comparative judgments. I predict that when a great judgmental weight can be assigned to DIFF L during the comparison process, this internal focus may create a decrease in NSSB as a function of judgmental order. For instance, if people are forced to restrain their excessive comparative judgments given that they must allocate some limited resource among all group members, the last group members would naturally receive a considerably lesser share than the first group members. By implication, training judges to think about within-group comparative judgments in terms of allocation of a limited resource might enhance their awareness of the internal differences within the group (i.e., DIFF L ), and this might reduce the sequential bias, or even the bias from the start. Further research can explore this line of reasoning.

div.head: Chapter 4: General Discussion
div.p: This research contrasted W-LOGE with unique attribute theory (in Chapter 2), and W-LOGE and focalism (in Chapter 3). Chapter 2 showed the influence of withingroup similarities on NSSB. The three studies reported in this chapter showed that in line with the W-LOGE hypothesis, under a within-group similarities condition, the bias was greater than under a within-group dissimilarities condition. In Chapter 3, Studies 4 to 6 showed that the comparative bias does not diminish when all the local group members are reviewed one after the other. Studies 7 to 9 showed that by giving greater weight to the DIFF G , (using a within-group similarities manipulation) reviewing all group members one by one can even increase the bias size as a function of judgmental order.

The studies presented in this work support the W-LOGE hypotheses. I predicted that reducing the internal differences between the local group members (i.e., what makes each group member uniquely positive) leaves more room for the external differences between this group member and the (less positive) general standard (i.e., DIFF G ) and this diversion of focus from the within group differences to the difference between the group as a whole and the general standard consequently influences NSSB size. Chapter 3 provided evidence for this hypothesis. Studies 7-9 in Chapter 3

showed that giving greater weight to the DIFF G via the similarity focus manipulation can even lead to increasing NSSB when the latter group members are perceived as even comparatively better than the former. This "accelerated NSSB effect" can only occur when more weight is given to the DIFF G during the comparison process. More specifically, the positivity of the judged group is augmented each time that a group member is judged and the positive distance vis-Ã -vis the general standard becomes larger with each successive comparative judgment.

These results lead to the conclusion that the weight attributed to DIFF G during the comparison process plays a major role in NSSB size, in both singular and sequential comparative judgments. All this might imply that in contrast to other internal accounts which assume that NSSB occurs exclusively within the local group, W-LOGE shows that the NSSB also occurs by an external mechanism.

div.head: What About Additional Alternative Internal Explanations?
div.p: The studies reported here contrasted the W-LOGE approach, an outgrowth of the LOGE account (Giladi & Klar, 2002), with the unique attributes (Chambers, 2010) and focalism accounts (e.g., Chambers & Suls, 2007;Klar & Giladi, 1997;Moore & Kim, 2003;Moore & Small, 2007;Windschitl, Kruger & Simms, 2003).

However there are several other internal accounts of NSSB that were not explicitly explored in this work. In this section I will present and attempt to discuss them in the light of the present results or utilize them to point out possible limitations on the current W-LOGE account, which call for further investigation.

div.head: Informational Differences
div.p: Some internal NSSB accounts focus on the way in which informational differences between one group member and the other members in the group can produce NSSB. These accounts assume that a better known group member will be judged in more extreme terms than the other, less known members.

account. In this reasoning, whenever people are more familiar with one entity in the group than the others, they will tend to judge this entity more extremely and make less extreme (i.e., more regressive) judgments regarding the lesser-known entities. A similar explanation known as "rational discounting" was put forward by Kruger, Windschitl, Burrus, Fessel and Chambers (2008). They posited that judges focus rationally on the knowledge most readily available to them. Therefore, they will focus on the best known entity and use it to conclude about less known entities in the group. Kruger et al. (2008) showed that the bias is reduced when people are exposed to the same amount of knowledge about the referent as well.

However, the information explanation is extraneous to the occurrence of NSSB as demonstrated in the current work, for several reasons. First, the random nature of the selection of the judged group members clearly limits the value of informational explanations. It is unreasonable to assume that each randomly chosen group member is better known than the other group members. Second, as demonstrated in the current studies, the NSSB was retained even when all the group members were judged one-by-one vis-Ã -vis the others in the group and even when this procedure was repeated twice; hence although the amount of knowledge about the non-focal members gradually increased, and towards the end of the first round of comparisons was complete, the NSSB effect remained intact. Moreover, Klar and Giladi (1997) showed that even an anonymous and therefore unindividuated TAU student was judged as better than the average TAU student. In these studies, judges could have a better grasp of the quality of the average TAU student than that of an anonymous TAU student but nevertheless the less known group member was judged as above the group's average.

div.head: Individual-Group Differences
div.p: Another line of reasoning regarding NSSB focuses on the differences between a singular group member and an aggregate entity composed of a collection of group members or the group as a whole. Sears' (1983) person positivity bias suggested that each individual person will be judged more favorably than an aggregation of persons;

thus, according to this approach, every individualistic marker will make the judged entity more positivity evaluated compared to a group or a group's representation. Krizan and Suls (2008) also proposed a similar explanation they dubbed the "diffuse general group", and suggested that it simply is easier to create an impression about a single group member than about a group as a whole, which is a larger and more diffuse entity. Still another individual-group explanation deals with abstraction levels: Price (2001) suggested that individuals are always judged to be better than their group, due to the fact that individuals are less abstract entities than their groups.

The results of Studies 1-3 make a case for the opposite possibility that the entire positive group can sometimes be superior to its individual members. That is, thinking about a positive group as a whole (via the within group similarities manipulation) may create an even larger NSSB than thinking about singular group members as individuals (via the within group differences manipulation). In particular, Study 3 showed that even within the same group, focusing on the group as a whole (via the similarities manipulation) created greater biases than focusing on the individual group members (via the dissimilarities condition). These results are problematic for the abstraction level explanation which assumes that the group is more abstract than the individuals and therefore less desirably judged.

In contrast to these internal accounts, our reasoning is that the bias does not necessarily occur due to the difference between the individual and the local group as a whole (i.e., DIFF L ), but due to the difference between the group as a whole and the general standard (i.e., DIFF G ). Therefore, when the group is positive compared to the general standard, individual group members, some group members, or even the group as a whole can be judged as positive compared to the general standard. Greater within-group similarities and focusing on what is common to all the group members might in some cases create greater biases since it might better emphasize the difference between the local group and the general standard.

The results reported in the Suls et al. (2010) studies provide additional support for this possibility. Suls et al. showed that a singular group member was perceived as better than the others in its group, while an aggregation of some group members were not judged as better than the group. However, when participants were asked to think of the coherent impression of aggregated group members or a singular group member, greater biases were found under the group cohesiveness condition than under the single group member impression condition. They summed up their results by saying:

"The results of both conditions support the idea that a set of ad hoc exemplars serving as a target will receive more weight than a single-item referent if judges are given preliminary instructions to think of the exemplars as a cohesive entity." (p. 69). This somewhat unexpected result by Suls et al (2010) can be easily explicated in terms of the W-LOGE reasoning. Specifically, it follows from Suls et al. (2010) that it is not the focus on the group that creates larger NSSBs, but rather the focus on the group cohesiveness. Or, in W-LOGE terms, it is the focus on the within-group similarities.

However, according to W-LOGE, the within-group similarities condition will only increase bias size when the group is judged as positive compared to the general standard. Windschitl, Conybeare and Krizan (2008) conducted two experiments in which participants were asked to imagine that they were given a sofa for free: they could either choose to get one specific sofa, or get one sofa selected at random from a group of four sofas. Participants in both experiments judged the single sofa to be less desirable than the group of four sofas, and they also preferred to get a sofa selected at random from the group of four sofas. However, consistent with the W-LOGE account this occurred only in the attractive sofa condition. No effect was found in the fair sofas condition. Niewiarowski, KaryÅowski, Szutkiewicz-Szekalska and CypryaÅska (2014) replicated the Windschitl et al. effect and also found that the larger the group, the greater the effects.

Thus, overall, the evidence for the notion that positive individuals are always better than their positive groups is mixed at best. According to W-LOGE, however, both positive individuals and positive groups can generate a NSSB as long they are superior to the general standard. Further research examining the W-LOGE hypothesis about NSSB reduction within fair groups is obviously needed.

In conclusion, I briefly reviewed some additional alternative explanations for the NSSB phenomenon. All these explanations are internal explanations because they assume that the bias is due to the comparative processes within the local group.
Although this might be the case, the results presented in this section favor the W-LOGE account, which also include external components of the bias.

div.head: Limitations & Further research
div.p: This work presented the W-LOGE, a better specified version of LOGE theory (Giladi & Klar, 2002). According to W-LOGE, DIFF L and DIFF G can receive different judgmental weights during the comparison process. In this work I attempted to vary these relative weights by using within-group similarities (vs. dissimilarities) manipulations. These manipulations indeed led to the theoretically predicted (and counter intuitive) effects of W-LOGE. However, in the current work, the "weights" concept remained an implied (or latent) rather than a directly assessed construct.

Further research should look for 'process' evidence (Hogarth, 1981), such as eyemovement tracking methods to identify how participants' attention is allocated when both internal and external visual stimuli are present (see for instance Manning, Ethell & Donovan, 2004). These methods might make it possible to determine whether participants pay different amounts of attention to the internal (i.e., DIFF L ) and the external (i.e., DIFF G ) in different experimental conditions, and whether degree of attention is related to the magnitudes of the biases.

Variations in the magnitudes of the biases were obtained in the current studies by varying the internal similarity / dissimilarity as a means to change the DIFF L -DIFF G balance. As already discussed, the magnitude of the biases is also affected, according to LOGE, by the distance between the entire local group and the general standard (i.e., DIFF G ). This was demonstrated in one study (Giladi & Klar, 2002;Study 6). Further research in this direction should also help sketch a fuller picture regarding the non-selective biases and their origins.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: This research aimed to extend the utility of LOGE theory as an "external" account of non-selective biases and contrast it with two leading "internal" accounts of these biases, the focalism and unique attribute approaches by adding the construct of judgmental weights and manipulating it via within group similarities and dissimilarities. These variations reliably affected the magnitude of NSSB, consistent with the LOGE and W-LOGE predictions.

div.p: both NSSB and NSIB in the successive judgments under the similarity condition further challenged the internal accounts, and further reinforced the "external" view.

Future research should attempt to investigate the use of the general standard, and ways to reduce its use to make more rational judgments and decisions. Meanwhile, Anna will probably continue judging each of her most liked musical pieces as better than the other pieces in her shortlist of most liked musical pieces.
